Geometric Representation Condition Improves Equivariant Molecule Generation

Zian Li1,2, Cai Zhou3,4, Xiyuan Wang1,2, Xingang Peng1,2, Muhan Zhang1
1Institute for Artificial Intelligence, Peking University
2School of Intelligence Science and Technology, Peking University
3Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
4Department of Automation, Tsinghua University
zian@stu.pku.edu.cn, muhan@pku.edu.cn Corresponding Author.
Abstract

Recent advancements in molecular generative models have demonstrated substantial potential in accelerating scientific discovery, particularly in drug design. However, these models often face challenges in generating high-quality molecules, especially in conditional scenarios where specific molecular properties must be satisfied. In this work, we introduce GeoRCG, a general framework to enhance the performance of molecular generative models by integrating geometric representation conditions. We decompose the molecule generation process into two stages: first, generating an informative geometric representation; second, generating a molecule conditioned on the representation. Compared to directly generating a molecule, the relatively easy-to-generate representation in the first-stage guides the second-stage generation to reach a high-quality molecule in a more goal-oriented and much faster way. Leveraging EDM as the base generator, we observe significant quality improvements in unconditional molecule generation on the widely-used QM9 and GEOM-DRUG datasets. More notably, in the challenging conditional molecular generation task, our framework achieves an average 31% performance improvement over state-of-the-art approaches, highlighting the superiority of conditioning on semantically rich geometric representations over conditioning on individual property values as in previous approaches. Furthermore, we show that, with such representation guidance, the number of diffusion steps can be reduced to as small as 100 while maintaining superior generation quality than that achieved with 1,000 steps, thereby significantly accelerating the generation process.

1 Introduction

Recent years have seen rapid development in generative modeling techniques for molecule generationÂ (GarciaÂ Satorras etÂ al., 2021; Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022; Luo & Ji, 2022; Wu etÂ al., 2022; Xu etÂ al., 2023; Morehead & Cheng, 2024), which have demonstrated great promise in accelerating scientific discoveries such as drug designÂ (Graves etÂ al., 2020). By modeling molecules as point clouds of chemical elements embedded in Euclidean space and employing equivariant models as backbone architectures, such as EGNNÂ (Satorras etÂ al., 2021), these approaches can ensure the O(3)- (or SO(3)-) invariance of the modeled molecule probability and have shown significant promise in both unconditional and conditional molecule generations.

Despite the advances, precisely modeling the molecular distribution qâ¢(â„³)ğ‘â„³q(\mathcal{M})italic_q ( caligraphic_M ) still remains a challenge, with current models often falling short of satisfactory results. This is especially true in the more practical scenarios where the goal is to capture the conditional distribution qâ¢(â„³|c)ğ‘conditionalâ„³ğ‘q(\mathcal{M}|c)italic_q ( caligraphic_M | italic_c ) for conditional generation, with cğ‘citalic_c representing a desired property such as the HOMO-LUMO gap. In such cases, recent models still produce molecules with property errors significantly larger than the data lower boundÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022; Xu etÂ al., 2023). Such challenge arises partly because molecules are naturally supported on a lower-dimensional manifoldÂ (Mislow, 2012; DeÂ Bortoli, 2022; You etÂ al., 2023), yet are embedded in a 3D space with much higher ambient dimensions (NÃ—(3+d)ğ‘3ğ‘‘N\times(3+d)italic_N Ã— ( 3 + italic_d ), where Nğ‘Nitalic_N is the number of atoms and dğ‘‘ditalic_d the atom feature dimension). Consequently, directly learning these distributions without additional guidance or conditioning solely on a single property can result in substantial errorsÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021), often leading to unstable or undesirable molecular samples.

In this work, we propose GeoRCG (Geometric-Representation-Conditioned Molecule Generation), a general framework for improving the generation quality of molecular generative models by leveraging geometric representation conditions for both unconditional and conditional generation. See FigureÂ 1 for an overview of the framework. At a high level, rather than directly learning the extrinsic molecular distribution, we aim to first transform it into a more compact and semantically meaningful representation distribution, with the help of a well-pre-trained geometric encoder Eğ¸Eitalic_E such as UnimolÂ (Zhou etÂ al., 2023) and FradÂ (Feng etÂ al., 2023). This distribution is much simpler because it does not exhibit any group symmetries, such as Oâ¢(3)/Sâ¢Oâ¢(3)ğ‘‚3ğ‘†ğ‘‚3O(3)/SO(3)italic_O ( 3 ) / italic_S italic_O ( 3 ) and Sâ¢(N)ğ‘†ğ‘S(N)italic_S ( italic_N ) groups which are present in extrinsic molecular distributions. As a result, a lightweight representation generatorÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023) can effectively capture this reduced distribution. In the second stage, we employ a standard molecular generator to achieve the ultimate objective: molecular generation. Unlike conventional approaches, our molecular generator is directly informed by the first-stage geometric representation, which encapsulates crucial molecular structure and property information. This guidance enables the generation of high-quality molecular structures with improved fidelity.

Our approach is directly inspired by RCGÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023), which, however, focuses on image data with fixed size and positions and does not necessitate handling Euclidean and permutation symmetriesâ€”factors that are markedly different in molecular data. Compared to recent work GraphRCGÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2024), which applies the RCG framework to 2D graph data, we explicitly handle 3D geometry that is more complex due to the additional Euclidean symmetry. Moreover, we avoid the complicated step-wise bootstrapped training and sampling process proposed inÂ Wang etÂ al. (2024) that requires noise alignment, sequential training, and simultaneous encoder training. Instead, we employ a simple and intuitive framework that enables parallel training and leverages advanced pre-trained geometric encoders containing valuable external knowledgeÂ (Zaidi etÂ al., 2022; Feng etÂ al., 2023), thus achieving competitive results while avoiding complex training procedures. Notably, while Li etÂ al. (2023) primarily focus on empirical evaluation, we also provide theoretical characterizations of general representation-conditioned diffusion models for both unconditional and conditional generation, which offers a rigorous understanding of the improved performance.

To illustrate the effectiveness of our approach, we select one of the simplest and most classical equivariant generative models, EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022), as the base molecular generator of GeoRCG. Experimentally, our method achieves the following significant improvements:

  • â€¢

    Substantially enhancing the quality of the generated molecules on the widely used QM9 and GEOM-DRUG datasets. On QM9, GeoRCG not only improves the performance of EDM by a large margin, but also significantly surpasses several recent baselines with state-of-the-art performanceÂ (Wu etÂ al., 2022; Xu etÂ al., 2023; Morehead & Cheng, 2024; Song etÂ al., 2024a).

  • â€¢

    More remarkably, in conditional molecule generation tasks, GeoRCG yields an average 31% improvement in performance, while many contemporary models struggled to achieve even marginal gains.

  • â€¢

    By incorporating classifier-free guidance in the molecule generatorÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023) and employing low-temperature sampling for representation generationÂ (Ingraham etÂ al., 2023), GeoRCG demonstrate a flexible trade-off between molecular quality and diversity without additional training, which is especially advantageous in molecular generation tasks that prioritizes quality over diversity.

  • â€¢

    With the assistance of the representation guidance, GeoRCG can significantly reduce the number of diffusion steps needed, while preserving the molecular generation quality, thereby considerably accelerating the generation process.

2 Related Works

Molecular Generative Models

Early work has primarily focused on modeling molecules as 2D graphs (composed of atom types, connection, and edge types), utilizing 2D graph generative models to learn the graph distributionÂ (Vignac etÂ al., 2022; Jang etÂ al., 2023; Jo etÂ al., 2023; Luo etÂ al., 2023; Zhou etÂ al., 2024). However, since molecules inherently exist in 3D space, where physical laws govern their behavior and geometry provides critical information related to key properties, recent research has increasingly focused on utilizing 3D generative models to directly learn the geometric distribution by modeling molecules as point clouds of chemical elements. Notable early autoregressive models include G-SchNetÂ (Gebauer etÂ al., 2019) and G-SphereNetÂ (Luo & Ji, 2022). More recently, diffusion models have demonstrated effectiveness in this domain, as evidenced by models like EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022) and subsequent advancementsÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2023; Wu etÂ al., 2022; Morehead & Cheng, 2024) that enhance EDM with latent space, prior information and more powerful backbones respectively. Furthermore, recent advances in flow methodsÂ (Lipman etÂ al., 2022; Liu etÂ al., 2022b) have inspired the development of geometric, equivariant flow methods including EquiFMÂ (Song etÂ al., 2024b) and GOATÂ (Hong etÂ al., 2024), which can provide much faster molecule generation speed. Beyond these, there are also methods jointly model 2D and 3D informationÂ (Vignac etÂ al., 2023; You etÂ al., 2023; Irwin etÂ al., 2024) (also called 3D graphÂ (You etÂ al., 2023)), where a representative method is MiDiÂ (Vignac etÂ al., 2023) which uses a diffusion framework to jointly diffuse and denoise atom type, bond type, formal charges and coordinates.

Latent Generative Models

At a high level, our framework can also be viewed as a latent generative model, where data distributions are learned in a latent space (our stage 1) and decoded back through some decoder (our stage 2). Most prior works in this domain either focus on regular data forms with fixed positions and sizesÂ (Van DenÂ Oord etÂ al., 2017; Razavi etÂ al., 2019; Dai & Wipf, 2019; Aneja etÂ al., 2021; Rombach etÂ al., 2022; Li etÂ al., 2023), or on data without Euclidean symmetry and require explicit modelingÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2024). Molecular data, however, presents unique challenges in both aspects. One of the key issues in this context is how to define the latent spaceâ€”defining it as â€œlatent coordinates and featuresâ€ as in GeoLDMÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2023) still results in a geometrically structured and thus complex space, while defining it on representations as we do introduces the challenge of effectively â€œdecodingâ€ a global, non-symmetric embedding back into geometric objects. LGDÂ (Zhou etÂ al., 2024) trains a diffusion model on a unified Euclidean latent space obtained by jointly training a powerful encoder and a simple decoder, and performs both generation and prediction tasks focusing on 2D graphs. LDM-3DGÂ (You etÂ al., 2023) also adopts representation latent space but employs a cascaded (2D+3D) auto-encoder (AE) framework, where the decoder is designed (or trained) to be deterministic, rendering poor performance on the 3D part as evidenced in our experiments. In contrast, we model the decoder as a powerful generative model, focusing solely on geometric learning while demonstrating superior effectiveness. We leave the related works of pre-trained geometric encoders inÂ AppendixÂ A.

3.2 GeoRCG: Geometric-Representation-Conditioned Molecular Generation

Geometric Representation Generator

To improve the quality of the generated molecules, we propose first transforming the geometrically structured molecular distribution qâ¢(â„³)ğ‘â„³q(\mathcal{M})italic_q ( caligraphic_M ) into a non-geometric representation distribution qâ¢(r)ğ‘ğ‘Ÿq(r)italic_q ( italic_r ) using a well-pre-trained geometric encoder Eğ¸Eitalic_E that maps each molecule â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M to its representation rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. Learning the representation distribution qâ¢(r)ğ‘ğ‘Ÿq(r)italic_q ( italic_r ) is considerably easier, since representations do not exhibit any symmetry as in explicit molecular generative modelsÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2022; Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022). We thus leverage a simple yet effective MLP-based diffusion architecture proposed inÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023) for the representation generator pÏ†â¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğœ‘ğ‘Ÿp_{\varphi}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ), which adopts the DDIM architectureÂ (Song etÂ al., 2020) with MLP backbones and is optimized via the denoising score matching schemeÂ (Vincent, 2011).

One deviation from previous practicesÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023; Wang etÂ al., 2024) is that we additionally condition the representation generator on the moleculeâ€™s node number Nğ‘Nitalic_N by default111We omit the condition Nğ‘Nitalic_N in our probability decompositions and mathematical derivations for statement simplicity, as its inclusion does not affect the overall framework and conclusions.. This is crucial for ensuring consistency between the size of the representationâ€™s underlying molecule and the size of the molecule it guides to generate. Moreover, molecules with different sizes often have distinct modes in structures and propertiesÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022), which is reflected in their geometric representations learned by modern pre-trained geometric encodersÂ (Zhou etÂ al., 2023; Feng etÂ al., 2023), as shown inÂ FigureÂ 2. Balancing Quality and Diversity of Molecule Generation

In many scientific applications, researchers prioritize generating higher-quality molecules over more diverse ones. To address this preference, we introduce a feature that allows fine-grained control over the trade-off between diversity and quality in the sampling stage (thus without retraining). This is achieved by integrating two key techniques: low-temperature samplingÂ (Ho & Salimans, 2022) (controlled via the temperature ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T) for the representation generator, and classifier-free guidanceÂ (Ho & Salimans, 2022) (controlled via the coefficient wğ‘¤witalic_w) for the molecule generator. We provide more details about the two techniques inÂ AppendixÂ B. Combining the two features enables a flexible and explicit control, which we refer to as â€œBalancing Controllablilityâ€ and demonstrate its effectiveness inÂ SectionÂ 4.2.

Handling Conditional Molecule Generation

The framework discussed thus far focuses on unconditional molecule generation, where no specific property cğ‘citalic_c (e.g., HOMO energy) is pre-specified. However, for molecule generation, a more practical and desired scenario is conditional (also called controllable) generation, where additional conditions cğ‘citalic_c, such as HOMO-LUMO gap energy, is introduced, and our objective shifts to generating molecules from the distribution qâ¢(â„³|c)ğ‘conditionalâ„³ğ‘q(\mathcal{M}|c)italic_q ( caligraphic_M | italic_c ). In GeoRCG, this conditional generation is naturally decomposed as pÎ¸,Ï†â¢(â„³|c)=âˆ«pÎ¸â¢(â„³|r)â¢pÏ†â¢(r|c)â¢ğ‘‘rsubscriptğ‘ğœƒğœ‘conditionalâ„³ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğœƒconditionalâ„³ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ğœ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿğ‘differential-dğ‘Ÿp_{\theta,\varphi}(\mathcal{M}|c)=\int p_{\theta}(\mathcal{M}|r)p_{\varphi}(r|% c)\,dritalic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ , italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_M | italic_c ) = âˆ« italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_M | italic_r ) italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r | italic_c ) italic_d italic_r , meaning that we first generate a â€œproperty-meaningfulâ€ molecular representation rğ‘Ÿritalic_r, which is then independently used to condition the second-stage molecule generation. See FigureÂ 3 for illustration. A key advantage of this modeling approach is that, when different properties (e.g., HOMO, LUMO, GAP energy) need to be captured, only the representation generator requires retraining under the new conditions. This retraining is highly efficient due to the lightweight nature of the representation generator. Notably, GeoRCG demonstrates outstanding conditional generation performance, as shown inÂ SectionÂ 4.3. Moreover, we theoretically demonstrate that, under mild assumptions, the representation generator can provably estimate the conditional distribution and generate representations that lead to provable reward improvements toward the target, which subsequently benefits the second-stage generation. Further details are provided inÂ SectionÂ E.2.

4 Experiments

4.1 Experiment Setup

Datasets and Tasks

As a method for 3D molecule generation, we evaluate GeoRCG on the widely used datasets QM9Â (Ramakrishnan etÂ al., 2014) and GEOM-DRUGÂ (Gebauer etÂ al., 2019; 2022). We focus on two tasks: unconditional molecule generation, where the goal is to sample from qâ¢(â„³)ğ‘â„³q(\mathcal{M})italic_q ( caligraphic_M ), and conditional (or controllable) molecule generation, where a property cğ‘citalic_c is given, and we aim to sample from qâ¢(â„³|c)ğ‘conditionalâ„³ğ‘q(\mathcal{M}|c)italic_q ( caligraphic_M | italic_c ). To ensure fair comparisons, we follow the dataset split and configurations exactly as inÂ Anderson etÂ al. (2019); Hoogeboom etÂ al. (2022); Xu etÂ al. (2023). Without further clarification, we bold the highest scores and underline the second-highest one. Additionally, to illustrate the direct improvement over our base model, EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022), we display green numbers next to the score to indicate the average improvement, and red numbers to denote a decrease. All results are calculated based on 10k randomly sampled molecules, averaged over three runs, with standard errors reported in parentheses.

Instantiation of the Pre-trained Encoder

We employ FradÂ (Feng etÂ al., 2023), which was pre-trained on the PCQM4Mv2 datasetÂ (Nakata & Shimazaki, 2017) using a hybrid noise denoising objective, as the geometric encoder for QM9 dataset. For GEOM-DRUG, we adopt UnimolÂ (Zhou etÂ al., 2023) and pre-train it on the GEOM-DRUG dataset itself, since GEOM-DRUG contains distinct chemical elements not present in PCQM4Mv2 or other commonly used pre-training datasets such as ZINC or ChemBLÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021).

Baselines

A direct comparison is made with our base molecule generator, EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022). Additionally, we benchmark against the non-equivariant counterparts of EDM and GeoLDMÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2023), namely GDM(-AUG)Â (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022) and GraphLDM(-AUG)Â (Xu etÂ al., 2023), as well as the autoregressive method G-SchNetÂ (Gebauer etÂ al., 2019). For further comparison, we include advanced equivariant diffusion models like GeoLDMÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2023), EDM-BridgeÂ (Wu etÂ al., 2022), and GCDMÂ (Morehead & Cheng, 2024), along with fast equivariant flow-based methods such as E-NFÂ (GarciaÂ Satorras etÂ al., 2021), EquiFMÂ (Song etÂ al., 2024b), and GOATÂ (Hong etÂ al., 2024). A recent Bayesian-based method GeoBFNÂ (Song etÂ al., 2024a) is also considered for its high-quality samples. Finally, we extend the comparison to 2D and 3D methods like MiDiÂ (Vignac etÂ al., 2023) and LDM-3DGÂ (You etÂ al., 2023).

Additionally, we provide further experiments, including ablation studies on the pre-trained encoder, inÂ AppendixÂ D.

4.2 Unconditional Molecule Generation

We first evaluate the quality of unconditionally generated molecules from GeoRCG, with the commonly adopted validity and stability metrics for assessing moleculesâ€™ qualityÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022). SeeÂ AppendixÂ C for detailed descriptions of these metrics.

Main Results

We present the main results on the QM9 and DRUG datasets inÂ TableÂ 1. Below, we highlight the key findings: (i) Improvement over the base model (EDM): By leveraging geometric representations, GeoRCG significantly outperforms the base model, EDM, on both QM9 and DRUG datasets. Notably, on QM9, it increases stable molecules from 82%percent8282\%82 % to 93.9%percent93.993.9\%93.9 % and validity from 91.9%percent91.991.9\%91.9 % to 97.4%percent97.497.4\%97.4 %, while also improving molecule uniqueness. (ii) Superior performance compared to advanced methods: GeoRCG also surpasses included advanced models on the QM9 dataset. On the DRUG dataset, it outperforms models such as EDM-Bridge and GOAT, and gets a high score in validity. Although it falls short of achieving the best performance, we attribute this to the quality of the encoderâ€™s representations, as we pre-trained it on the GEOM-DRUG dataset, which may lack diversity and sufficient size. Crucially, many structures in GEOM-DRUG lack the equilibrium conditions necessary for pre-training methods that enable effective learning of force fieldsÂ (Zaidi etÂ al., 2022; Feng etÂ al., 2023). Additionally, GeoRCG adopts EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022) as the base molecule generator, which can be weaker compared to recent advanced models. Nevertheless, further improvement to GeoRCG can be achievabled by incorporating more advanced molecule generators or higher-quality pre-trained encoders.

Balancing Controllability

We proceed to investigate the â€œBalancing Controllablilityâ€â€ feature of GeoRCG introduced inÂ SectionÂ 3.2. To this end, we conducted a grid search by varying both wğ‘¤witalic_w and ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T on QM9 dataset, as depicted inÂ FigureÂ 4. The results indicate a clear trend: increasing wğ‘¤witalic_w and decreasing ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T improve validity and stability at the expense of uniqueness, allowing for fine-grained, flexible control over molecule generation. At its best, this approach achieves a molecule stability of 93.9% and a validity of 97.42%, approaching the datasetâ€™s upper bound, with a trade-off in lower uniqueness&validity of 86.82%.

Additional Comparison with 2D&3D methods

We further compare with recent 2D&3D methods, including MiDiÂ (Vignac etÂ al., 2023) and LDM-3DGÂ (You etÂ al., 2023), which jointly learn and generate both 2D bond information and 3D geometry. However, these models rely on external tools like RDKit or OpenBabelÂ (Oâ€™Boyle etÂ al., 2011) for bond computation at the input stage, which enables them to implicitly leverage domain knowledge of such tools. In contrast, purely 3D methods like GeoRCG and those in our primary comparison utilize a coarse look-up table for bond estimation, which, while reflecting 3D learning, results in less accurate bond calculation, potentially biasing the comparison. Therefore, to provide a reference, we also report the performance of our models combined with the same external tools (e.g., OpenBabel) for precise bond calculations in our generated 3D conformations. Furthermore, as GeoRCG essentially captures 3D geometric distributions, we place more emphasis on 3D metrics that directly evaluate 3D learning capabilities, including BondLengthW1 and BondAngleW1 proposed byÂ Vignac etÂ al. (2023) and detailed inÂ AppendixÂ C. The results inÂ TableÂ 2 demonstrate that GeoRCG not only significantly outperforms MiDi and LDM-3DG on 3D metrics, highlighting the advantages of using a pure 3D model for learning 3D structures, but also further enhances EDMâ€™s performance, which has already shown considerable promise in 3D learning.

We strictly follow the evaluation protocol outlined inÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022). Speicifically, QM9 is split into two halves, and an EGNN classifierÂ (Satorras etÂ al., 2021) is trained on the first half for evaluating the generated moleculesâ€™ property, while the generator is trained on the second half222Although FigureÂ 3 shows that retraining the molecule generator is unnecessary, for a fair comparison, we still retrain the molecule generator on the second half of the dataset, rather than using the one in unconditional molecule generation trained on the entire dataset.. We focus on six properties: polarizability (Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±), orbital energies (ÎµHOMOsubscriptğœ€HOMO\varepsilon_{\text{HOMO}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT HOMO end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ÎµLUMOsubscriptğœ€LUMO\varepsilon_{\text{LUMO}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT LUMO end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), their gap (Î”â¢ÎµÎ”ğœ€\Delta\varepsilonroman_Î” italic_Îµ), dipole moment (Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼), and heat capacity (Cvsubscriptğ¶ğ‘£C_{v}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

The results are presented inÂ TableÂ 3. The first three baselines, as introduced by EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022), represent the classifierâ€™s inherent bias as the lower bound for performance, the random evaluation result as the upper bound, and the dependency of properties on Nğ‘Nitalic_N. As shown, GeoRCG nearly doubles the performance of the best existing models for most properties, with an average 31%percent3131\%31 % improvement over the best ones. This is a task where many recent models struggle to make even modest improvements, as evidenced in the table. Notably, for different properties, we only re-train the representation generator, as demonstrated inÂ SectionÂ 3.2, significantly saving training time. InÂ FigureÂ 5, we visualize the generated samples, which exhibit minimal property errors and display a clear trend as the target values increase. Additional randomly generated molecules are provided inÂ SectionÂ F.2.

A potential concern is that for a given property value cğ‘citalic_c, pÏ†â¢(r|c)subscriptğ‘ğœ‘conditionalğ‘Ÿğ‘p_{\varphi}(r|c)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r | italic_c ) may produce a representation corresponding to a molecule from the training dataset, allowing the molecule generator to simply recover its full conformation based on that representation. This could lead to small property errors but a lack of novelty. To address this, we conducted a thorough evaluation of the generated molecules across each property, finding that the novelty (the proportion of new molecules not present in the training dataset) remains high at approximately 70%, comparable to other methods. Additionally, the conditionally generated molecules demonstrate much higher molecule stability than EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022). Further details can be found inÂ AppendixÂ D.

4.4 Faster Generation with Fewer Steps

With geometric representation condition, it is reasonable to expect that fewer discretization steps of the reverse diffusion SDEÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021) would still yield competitive results. Therefore, we reduce the number of diffusion steps and evaluate the modelâ€™s performance. The results are presented in TableÂ 4. As demonstrated, with the geometric representation condition, GeoRCG consistently outperforms other approaches across all step numbers. Notably, with approximately 100 steps, the performance of our method nearly converges to the optimal performance observed with 1000 steps, which already surpasses all other methods across all step numbers. This directly reflects the faster generation speed, as the time required for the first-stage representation generation is minimal and can be considered negligible.

5 Conclusions

In this work, we present GeoRCG, an effective framework for improving the generation quality of arbitrary molecule generators by incorporating geometric representation conditions. We use EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022) as the base molecule generator and demonstrate the effectiveness of our framework through extensive molecular generation experiments. Notably, in conditional generation tasks, GeoRCG achieves a 31% performance boost compared to recent state-of-the-art models. Additionally, the representation guidance enables significantly faster sampling with 10x fewer diffusion steps while maintaining near-optimal performance. Beyond these empirical improvements, we provide theoretical characterizations of general representation-conditioned generative models, which address a key gap in the existing literatureÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023).

One limitation of our framework is that its generation quality could depend on the representation quality. For instance, on the GEOM-DRUG dataset, where the encoder was less thoroughly pre-trained, the improvements were less pronounced, and GeoRCG did not surpass SOTA methods. Future work could focus on improving the effectiveness of pre-trained models or exploring enhanced representation regularization techniques. Furthermore, while we employ EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022) as the base molecule generator, our framework is general and can be applied to any molecular generative model. Integrating this framework with more advanced SOTA models offers a promising direction for future exploration and performance enhancement.

Appendix A More Related Works

Pre-training for Molecular Encoders

Learning meaningful molecular representations is crucial for downstream tasks like molecular property predictionÂ (Fang etÂ al., 2022). The paradigm of pre-training on large-scale datasets followed by fine-tuning on smaller datasets has been shown to significantly enhance model performance in both vision and language domainsÂ (Kenton & Toutanova, 2019; Brown, 2020; Dosovitskiy, 2020), and building on this success, recent studies have proposed self-supervised pre-training methods for point-cloud-formatted molecules, aiming to achieve similar performance gainsÂ (Zhou etÂ al., 2023; Feng etÂ al., 2023; Liu etÂ al., 2022a; Fang etÂ al., 2022; Jiao etÂ al., 2024; Ni etÂ al., 2024). Typical proxy tasks involve masking and recovering atom types, bond lengths, and bond anglesÂ (Fang etÂ al., 2022; Zhou etÂ al., 2023). However, since molecules reside in continuous 3D space, a more effective approach is to introduce carefully designed noise to the coordinates and train the model to denoise it. Examples include isotropic Gaussian noiseÂ (Zaidi etÂ al., 2022; Zhou etÂ al., 2023), Riemann-Gaussian noiseÂ (Jiao etÂ al., 2023), and complex hybrid noiseÂ (Ni etÂ al., 2024; Feng etÂ al., 2023; Jiao etÂ al., 2024). Notably,Â Zaidi etÂ al. (2022) demonstrated that denoising equilibrium structures corresponds to learning the force field, thereby producing representations that are both physically and chemically informative.

Appendix B Algorithms

Parallel Training and Sequential Sampling

We provide the high-level training and sampling algorithm for GeoRCG inÂ AlgorithmÂ 1.

Representation Perturbation

Unlike typical conditional training scenarios, GeoRCG faces a unique challenge: the representations that condition the molecule generator during training may not always coincide with those generated by the representation generator during the sampling stage. This issue is particularly pronounced in molecular generation than image caseÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023), where pre-trained encoders are typically not trained on that large datasets with advanced regularization techniques like MoCo v3Â (Chen etÂ al., 2021). Consequently, the molecule generator is susceptible to overfitting to the training representations, as evidenced by our preliminary experiments on QM9 molecule generation shown inÂ TableÂ 5.

We find that applying a simple way by perturbing the geometric representation with Gaussian noise Ïƒrepâ¢Ïµsubscriptğœrepitalic-Ïµ\sigma_{\text{rep}}\epsilonitalic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT rep end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ïµ (where Ïµâˆ¼ğ’©â¢(0,I)similar-toitalic-Ïµğ’©0ğ¼\epsilon\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I)italic_Ïµ âˆ¼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I ) and Ïƒrepsubscriptğœrep\sigma_{\text{rep}}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT rep end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a small variance) during the molecule generatorâ€™s training is particularly effective. Low-Temperature Sampling

We adopt the low-temperature sampling algorithm introduced by ChromaÂ (Ingraham etÂ al., 2023), however, applying it to an MLP-based diffusion model rather than the equivariant diffusion model that processes geometric objects as Chroma.

The objective of low-temperature sampling is to perturb the learned representation distribution pÏ†â¢(r)subscriptğ‘ğœ‘ğ‘Ÿp_{\varphi}(r)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) by rescaling it with an inverse temperature factor, 1ğ’¯1ğ’¯\frac{1}{\mathcal{T}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_T end_ARG, where ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T is a tunable temperature parameter during sampling, and finally enables sampling from ğ’µğ’¯â¢pÏ†1ğ’¯subscriptğ’µğ’¯superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğœ‘1ğ’¯\mathcal{Z}_{\mathcal{T}}p_{\varphi}^{\frac{1}{\mathcal{T}}}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG caligraphic_T end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ğ’µğ’¯subscriptğ’µğ’¯\mathcal{Z}_{\mathcal{T}}caligraphic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a normalization constant. The method proposed in ChromaÂ (Ingraham etÂ al., 2023) scales the score Ïµtsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘¡\epsilon_{t}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT estimated at each diffusion time step using a time-dependent factor Î»tsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡\lambda_{t}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The approach is derived from and has theoretical guarantees for simplified toy distributions, and its performance on complex distributions, though lacking strict guarantees, has shown consistent results when combined with annealed Langevin samplingÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021). Here we briefly introduce it for self-containess, and recommend the readers toÂ Ingraham etÂ al. (2023) for detailed derivation and illustration.

Consider the vanilla reverse SDE used in DDPM sampling (VP formulation)Â (Song etÂ al., 2021):

Classifier-Free Guidance

We employ the classifier-free guidance algorithm, as introduced inÂ (Ho & Salimans, 2022), for our molecule generator. Specifically, we introduce a trainable â€œfakeâ€ representation, denoted as lğ‘™litalic_l, which serves as the unconditional signal. During the training phase, lğ‘™litalic_l is initialized as learnable parameters, and with a probability of pfakesubscriptğ‘fakep_{\text{fake}}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT fake end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the true representation rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is replaced by lğ‘™litalic_l. This ensures that the model is capable of generating molecules unconditionally, i.e., pÎ¸â¢(â„³|l)subscriptğ‘ğœƒconditionalâ„³ğ‘™p_{\theta}(\mathcal{M}|l)italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_M | italic_l ) approximates qâ¢(â„³)ğ‘â„³q(\mathcal{M})italic_q ( caligraphic_M ). Appendix C Experiment Details

Metrics and Baseline Descriptions

We adopt the evaluation metrics, guidelines and baselines commonly used in prior 3D molecular generative models to ensure a fair comparisonÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022).

  • â€¢

    In the unconditional setting, we assess the generated molecules using several key metrics:

    • â€“

      Atom Stability: The proportion of atoms with correct valency.

    • â€“

      Molecule Stability: The proportion of molecules where all atoms within the molecule are stable.

    • â€“

      Validity: The proportion of molecules that can be converted into valid SMILES using RDKit.

    • â€“

      Validity & Uniqueness: The proportion of unique molecules among the valid molecules.

    Following prior work on direct 3D molecular conformations â„³=(ğ±,ğ¡)â„³ğ±ğ¡\mathcal{M}=(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{h})caligraphic_M = ( bold_x , bold_h )Â (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022), we infer bond information based on atom types and bond lengths using look-up table methods.

    Following the approach ofÂ Hoogeboom etÂ al. (2022); Vignac & Frossard (2021), we do not report Novelty scores in the main text, since QM9 represents an exhaustive enumeration of molecules satisfying a predefined set of constraints, therefore, â€œnovelâ€ molecule would necessarily violate at least one of these constraints, which indicates that a model fails to fully capture the properties of the dataset. Consistent withÂ Hoogeboom etÂ al. (2022), we observe that the novelty score decreases as stability and validity scores improve, eventually stabilizing at approximately 60%. This is comparable to the final novelty score of EDM, which is around 65% (seeÂ TableÂ 8).

    When comparing with 2D & 3D models, we evaluate two 3D metrics introduced by MiDiÂ (Vignac etÂ al., 2023), which directly assess the geometry learning ability:

    • â€“

      BondLengthW1: The weighted 1-Wasserstein distance between the bond-length distributions of the generated molecules and the training dataset, with weights corresponding to different bond types.

    • â€“

      BondAngleW1: The weighted 1-Wasserstein distance between the atom-centered angle distributions of the generated molecules and the training dataset, with weights based on atom types.

    They are formally defined as:

    In the conditional generation setting, as described inÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022), we evaluate our approach on the QM9 dataset across six properties: polarizability Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, orbital energies ÎµHOMOsubscriptğœ€HOMO\varepsilon_{\text{HOMO}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT HOMO end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ÎµLUMOsubscriptğœ€LUMO\varepsilon_{\text{LUMO}}italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT LUMO end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and their gap Î”â¢ÎµÎ”ğœ€\Delta\varepsilonroman_Î” italic_Îµ, dipole moment Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼, and heat capacity Cvsubscriptğ¶ğ‘£C_{v}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The generative model is trained conditionally on the second half of the QM9 dataset, and an EGNNÂ (Satorras etÂ al., 2021) classifier, trained on the first half, is employed to evaluate the MAE property error of the generated samples.

    Three baselines are adopted inÂ TableÂ 3:

    • â€“

      QM9 (lower bound): The mean error of a classifier trained on the first half of the QM9 dataset and evaluated on the second half. This baseline represents the inherent bias/error of the classifier, setting a lower bound for model performance and reflecting the best possible performance a model can achieve.

    • â€“

      Random: The classifierâ€™s performance when evaluated on the second half of QM9 with randomly shuffled molecule property labels. This baseline provides an upper bound, representing the worst achievable performance.

    • â€“

      N_atoms: The performance of a classifier trained exclusively on the number of atoms Nğ‘Nitalic_N and evaluated using only Nğ‘Nitalic_N as input. This baseline captures the intrinsic relationship between molecular properties and the number of atoms, which a generative model must surpass to demonstrate effectiveness.

Model Architectures, Hyperparameters and Training Details
  • â€¢

    Representation Generator. We use the same architecture for the representation generator as the MLP-based diffusion model proposed inÂ Li etÂ al. (2023). We use 18 blocks of residual MLP layers with 1536 hidden dimensions, 1000 diffusion steps, and a linear noise schedule for Î²tsubscriptğ›½ğ‘¡\beta_{t}italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The representation generator is trained for 2000 epochs with a batch size of 128 for both the QM9 and DRUG datasets. Training on QM9 takes approximately 2.5 days on a single Nvidia 4090, while training on DRUG takes around 4 days on a single Nvidia A800. Training time can indeed be further reduced, as the model shows minimal progress after approximately half of the reported time.

  • â€¢

    Molecule Generator. We adopt EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022) as the base molecule generator, using the same EGNNÂ (Satorras etÂ al., 2021) architecture, with the exception of the conditioning module. Specifically, we incorporate a cross-attentionÂ (Vaswani, 2017) module for better conditioning on representations, placing it between every block of the EGNN to enhance regularization and increase expressiveness. For the EGNN hyperparameters, we use 9 layers with 256 hidden dimensions for QM9 and 4 layers with 256 hidden dimensions for DRUG. The number of diffusion steps is set to 1000 (except for cases inÂ TableÂ 4 that generate molecules with fewer steps), and we employ the polynomial scheduler for Î±t(â„³)superscriptsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡â„³\alpha_{t}^{(\mathcal{M})}italic_Î± start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_M ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Notably, all model hyperparameters are identical to those in EDM for fair comparison. During training, we use a batch size of 128 and 3000 epochs on QM9, and a batch size of 64 and 20 epochs on DRUG. The representation perturbation values are set to Ïƒrep=0.3subscriptğœrep0.3\sigma_{\text{rep}}=0.3italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT rep end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.3 on QM9 and Ïƒrep=0.5subscriptğœrep0.5\sigma_{\text{rep}}=0.5italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT rep end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5 on DRUG. Training takes approximately 6 days on QM9 using a single Nvidia 4090, and around 10 days on DRUG using two Nvidia A800 GPUs.

  • â€¢

    Sampling Details. During representation sampling, we use the predictor-corrector method fromÂ Song etÂ al. (2021) for VP SDE to achieve better equilibrium distributions, which facilitates low-temperature sampling. For molecule sampling, the process remains the same as in EDM, with the addition of classifier-free guidance. For the unconditional generation results inÂ TableÂ 1, we use (w,ğ’¯)=(1.0,1.0)ğ‘¤ğ’¯1.01.0(w,\mathcal{T})=(1.0,1.0)( italic_w , caligraphic_T ) = ( 1.0 , 1.0 ) in the QM9 dataset, except for the results inÂ FigureÂ 4, and (w,ğ’¯)=(0.0,0.5)ğ‘¤ğ’¯0.00.5(w,\mathcal{T})=(0.0,0.5)( italic_w , caligraphic_T ) = ( 0.0 , 0.5 ) in the GEOM-DRUG dataset (note that w=0.0ğ‘¤0.0w=0.0italic_w = 0.0 indicates that we do not use classifier-free guidance, not that the representation condition itself is not applied). Further tuning of these two hyperparameters may lead to improved results.

Evaluation of LDM-3DGÂ (You etÂ al., 2023)

We evaluate the performance of LDM-3DGÂ (You etÂ al., 2023), an Auto-Encoder-based method that also leverages the compactness of the representation space to achieve good performance.

  • â€¢

    For the unconditional results inÂ TableÂ 1, we utilize the 3D conformations unconditionally generated by LDM-3DGÂ (You etÂ al., 2023) and compute the bond information using the look-up table method from EDMÂ (Hoogeboom etÂ al., 2022). Notably, although LDM-3DG predicts both the 2D molecular graph and the 3D conformation, we do not use the bond information it predicts for the following reasons:

    1. 1.

      For the calculation of 3D geometry statistics, we observe significant inconsistencies between the generated 2D graphs and 3D geometries (e.g., valid molecules with bond lengths exceeding 100â¢m100m100\,\text{m}100 m), leading to unreliable statistics (e.g., BondLengthW1 exploding to 3900).

    2. 2.

      For stability and validity metrics, which are fundamentally 2D and computed based on molecular graphs (atoms and bond types), using the generated 2D graph would ignore the contribution of the 3D module, preventing an evaluation of its 3D learning performance.

    3. 3.

      Most critically, their 2D module is explicitly designed to filter out invalid (sub-)molecules during generation using the RDKit method. This means that if invalid molecules or sub-molecules are generated, they are regenerated. This explicit filtering deviates from our standard evaluation criteria and is unsuitable for a fair comparison.

  • â€¢

    For the conditional results inÂ TableÂ 3, we first note a potential issue with LDM-3DGÂ (You etÂ al., 2023): The model cannot explicitly specify the node number Nğ‘Nitalic_N during molecule generation, as it uses an auto-regressive 2D generator that automatically stops adding atoms/motifs when deemed sufficient. However, the evaluation inÂ TableÂ 3 requires specifying both Nğ‘Nitalic_N and property cğ‘citalic_c, following the ground-truth distribution qâ¢(N,c)ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘q(N,c)italic_q ( italic_N , italic_c ) from the training dataset. To ensure fair evaluation, conditions feeding to LDM-3DG must also satisfy this distribution. As the authors claim the model can implicitly learn qâ¢(N)ğ‘ğ‘q(N)italic_q ( italic_N ) and thus qâ¢(N|c)ğ‘conditionalğ‘ğ‘q(N|c)italic_q ( italic_N | italic_c ), we first sample 10,000 values from qâ¢(c)ğ‘ğ‘q(c)italic_q ( italic_c ) and feed them to LDM-3DG, expecting it to infer Nğ‘Nitalic_N from cğ‘citalic_c implicitly as argued, and thus matching the qâ¢(N,c)ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘q(N,c)italic_q ( italic_N , italic_c ) conditions.

Appendix D Additional Experiment Results

Ablation Study: Representation Encoders

Geometric representations play a pivotal role in GeoRCG. To evaluate the importance of representation quality, we conduct an ablation study comparing the quality of molecule samples generated by GeoRCG trained under different geometric encoder configurations.

We first assess the benefits provided by the pre-training stage. Specifically, we utilize the pre-trained encoder FradÂ (Feng etÂ al., 2023), trained on the PCQM4Mv2 datasetÂ (Nakata & Shimazaki, 2017) with a hybrid coordinates denoising taskÂ (Feng etÂ al., 2023). This approach has been proven to equivalently learn force fieldsÂ (Feng etÂ al., 2023; Zaidi etÂ al., 2022), and is therefore expected to produce informative representations that capture high-level molecular information. We train GeoRCG using representations from a well-pretrained Frad and a Frad with randomly initialized weights. The molecule generation quality on QM9, as shown inÂ TableÂ 6, clearly underscores the critical role of pre-training on large datasets with advanced techniques in improving representation quality, ultimately enhancing GeoRCGâ€™s performance.

Next, we investigate the impact of different pre-trained encoders, which could vary in model structure and proxy tasks used for pre-training. Specifically, we compare UnimolÂ (Zhou etÂ al., 2023), which employs a message-passing neural network framework incorporating distance features (i.e., DisGNN inÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023; 2024b)) and primarily uses naive coordinates denoising, with FradÂ (Feng etÂ al., 2023), which adopts TorchMDÂ (ThÃ¶lke & DeÂ Fabritiis, 2022) as the backbone and utilizes carefully designed hybrid-denoising tasks. Both UnimolÂ (Zhou etÂ al., 2023) and FradÂ (Feng etÂ al., 2023) are pre-trained on the GEOM-DRUG dataset until convergence. We visualize the T-SNE of the representations generated for GEOM-DRUG. As shown inÂ FigureÂ 6, the T-SNE of the Unimol representations exhibits a clearer clustering pattern based on node numbers compared to the Frad representations, which may suggest better representation learning. To further investigate, we utilize both encoders to train GeoRCG and subsequently evaluate the quality of molecule generation. The Frad-based GeoRCG achieves a Validity of 96.9â¢(0.44)96.90.4496.9(0.44)96.9 ( 0.44 ) and Atom Stability of 84.4â¢(0.27)84.40.2784.4(0.27)84.4 ( 0.27 ), while the Unimol-based GeoRCG achieves a Validity of 98.5â¢(0.12)98.50.1298.5(0.12)98.5 ( 0.12 ) and Atom Stability of 84.3â¢(0.12)84.30.1284.3(0.12)84.3 ( 0.12 ): Although the Frad-based GeoRCG produces slightly higher atom stability, its high variance and significantly lower validity suggest inferior performance. These findings, along with our main results, offer insights into the types of representations more effective for guiding molecule generation, suggesting that sensitivity to molecule size may be a critical factor.

Ablation Study: Representation Perturbation

As discussed inÂ AppendixÂ B, we investigate the effectiveness of the straightforward representation perturbation technique by introducing random noise to perturb the representations during training. Additionally, we apply extra dropout in the conditioning module of our molecule generator to mitigate overfitting on the representation conditions. Ablation experiments presented inÂ TableÂ 7 demonstrate the efficacy of these simple yet impactful methods.

Appendix E Theoretical Analysis

In this section, we provide rigorous theoretical analysis on representation-conditioned diffusion models. Our theory is not limited to molecule generation, and is the first theoretical breakthrough for the RCG frameworkÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023).

Our analysis is organized as follows. In SectionÂ E.1, we analyze the generation bound of representation-conditioned diffusion models in unconditional generation tasks by showing: (i) the representation can be well generated by the first-stage diffusion model with mild assumptions (SectionÂ E.1.1); (ii) the second-stage representation-conditioned diffusion model exhibits no higher generalization error than traditional one-stage diffusion model, and can arguably achieve lower error leveraging the informative representations (SectionÂ E.1.2). Then in SectionÂ E.2, we analyze conditional generation tasks as follows: (iii) under mild assumptions of representations and targets, we provide novel bound for score estimation error (SectionÂ E.2.1); (iv) generated representations have provable reward improvement towards the target, with the suboptimality composed of offline regression error and diffusion distribution shift (SectionÂ E.2.2), thus would improve the second stage of conditional generation (SectionÂ E.2.3).

Notations.

In this section, we use SDE and score matching formulations of diffusion models to present our theoretical results, given their equivalence with the DDPM familyÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021). We consider the random variable xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and use qâ¢(â‹…)ğ‘â‹…q(\cdot)italic_q ( â‹… ) to denote the ground truth distributions, pâ¢(â‹…)ğ‘â‹…p(\cdot)italic_p ( â‹… ) to denote the posterior distribution predicted by diffusion models. We finally conclude with Pinskerâ€™s inequality (TV2â‰¤KLsuperscriptTV2KL\text{TV}^{2}\leq\text{KL}TV start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ KL). âˆ

This result holds for general representation-conditioned diffusion models, and to our best knowledge we are the first to provide theories for representation-conditioned generation, which is a general generation framework suitable for various domains such as imagesÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023) and graphs.

LemmaÂ E.1 quantitatively characterizes the bound on generalization error in representation-conditioned diffusion. It directly suggests that the error of representation-conditioned diffusion will be no higher than that of its one-stage counterpart. This is because the first two components of the generalization error (i.e., the convergence of the forward process and the discretization error) of the representation-conditioned diffusion model align with those of traditional DDPM, provided that both are parameterized using the same diffusion processes. Furthermore, the third component (score estimation error) can be made identical if we simply set all representation-relevant parameters in sÎ¸subscriptğ‘ ğœƒs_{\theta}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to zero and disregard representationâ€™s impact. We therefore have the following conclusion,

Corollary E.1.

Self-representation-conditioned diffusion model can have the same or a lower generation distribution error than one-stage diffusion model.

This is because the former is the score estimation error based on explicit relationship between xğ‘¥xitalic_x and rğ‘Ÿritalic_r while the latter learns implicitly. Thus, TheoremÂ E.1 is a much tighter bound for representation-conditioned generation. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first rigorous theoretical analysis on RCGÂ (Li etÂ al., 2023). We now provide some qualitative discussions on why representations can arguably lead to better generalization error.

Typically, representations are powerful (and sometimes even complete) as they encode key information about xğ‘¥xitalic_x with potential additional knowledge via pretraining tasks (for example, coordinates denoising for moleculesÂ (Zaidi etÂ al., 2022; Feng etÂ al., 2023)). Therefore, it is reasonable to expect that score estimation conditioned on representations can be more accurate (i.e., ÏµÎ¸,scoresubscriptitalic-Ïµğœƒscore\epsilon_{\theta,\rm score}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ , roman_score end_POSTSUBSCRIPT could be significantly smaller than when estimating the score without representation conditioning). If the representations are completeâ€”where a special case would be r=xğ‘Ÿğ‘¥r=xitalic_r = italic_xâ€”this would greatly assist in predicting the noise. The same applies when rğ‘Ÿritalic_r can be properly transformed back to xğ‘¥xitalic_x by a neural network. More generally, there are intermediate cases where rğ‘Ÿritalic_r reflects partial information about xğ‘¥xitalic_x (e.g., a multiset of atoms and bonds), which would still aid in improving prediction.

To conclude this subsection, we provide a detailed characterization of the generalization error of representation-conditioned diffusion models. It is important to note that some parameters in our assumptions, such as Lipschitz scores and estimation errors, are not constants; they are functions of the SDE total time Tğ‘‡Titalic_T and the number of diffusion steps Nğ‘Nitalic_N. Our conclusions also explain why representation-conditioned generation methods remain competitive even when the number of second-stage diffusion steps Nğ‘Nitalic_N is decreased for faster generation. This is because the score estimation error can remain small even when the number of diffusion steps is reduced, given the guidance from representations. As a result, reducing Nğ‘Nitalic_N causes a slower increase in ÏµÏ†,Î¸,condâ¢(N)subscriptitalic-Ïµğœ‘ğœƒcondğ‘\epsilon_{\varphi,\theta,\rm cond}(N)italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Ï† , italic_Î¸ , roman_cond end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_N ) compared to the score estimation error without representation conditioning, leading to representation-conditioned generative modelsâ€™ strong performance with fewer steps.

E.2.3 Second Stage of Conditional Generation

Now that we have proved that: (i) the first-stage diffusion model can estimate the score function with provable error bound (SectionÂ E.2.1); and (ii) the generated representations have provable reward improvement (SectionÂ E.2.2). We continue to show that the ultimate generated samples also have distribution shift towards the desired target in the following contexts. Particularly, we want to answer the question: why utilizing the conditionally generated representations is enough for the second stage generation?

First, when we use the generated representations as the only condition of the second stage diffusion model, the generation process is identical to the second stage of unconditional generation. Therefore, the results in SectionÂ E.1.2 can be directly applied to analyze the second stage generation of conditional generation, which states that the generation conditioning on representations has small TV distance error compared with ground truth conditional distribution. Thus, when we have high-quality first-stage generation, the corresponding second stage generation would introduce almost no additional error, which implies provable reward improvements towards the desired target. In addition, the well-pretrained encode ensures that the correspondence between representations and data points is good, which makes it possible to rigorously construct the data points given the representations (a special case would be rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is the complete representation of xğ‘¥xitalic_x).

We then partially answer this question from the information theoretic perspectives. We use Hâ¢(â‹…)ğ»â‹…H(\cdot)italic_H ( â‹… ) to denote the information entropy, and Iâ¢(â‹…;â‹…)ğ¼â‹…â‹…I(\cdot;\cdot)italic_I ( â‹… ; â‹… ) to denote the mutual information between two variables.

  • â€¢

    Iâ¢(x;r)â‰¥Iâ¢(x;y)ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘¦I(x;r)\geq I(x;y)italic_I ( italic_x ; italic_r ) â‰¥ italic_I ( italic_x ; italic_y ). On the one hand, rğ‘Ÿritalic_r contains enough information to recover the targets yğ‘¦yitalic_y thanks to the results in SectionÂ E.2.2, thus we do not explicitly need yğ‘¦yitalic_y for the second stage. One the other hand, benefit from the pretraining task, the representations obviously contains more information in addition to yğ‘¦yitalic_y. This assumption is valid if wâˆ—superscriptğ‘¤w^{*}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in previous analysis is sparse (there are components in rğ‘Ÿritalic_r independent of yğ‘¦yitalic_y), i.e., Hâ¢(r)>Hâ¢(y)ğ»ğ‘Ÿğ»ğ‘¦H(r)>H(y)italic_H ( italic_r ) > italic_H ( italic_y ). Therefore, generating xğ‘¥xitalic_x conditioning on rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is much easier than generating conditioning on yğ‘¦yitalic_y (traditional one stage generation), as the score estimation error of the former one would obviously be much smaller than the latter.

  • â€¢

    Iâ¢(x,r;y)â‰¥Iâ¢(x;y)ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘Ÿğ‘¦ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘¦I(x,r;y)\geq I(x;y)italic_I ( italic_x , italic_r ; italic_y ) â‰¥ italic_I ( italic_x ; italic_y ). Recall EquationÂ 44 which states the target property yğ‘¦yitalic_y depends on both xğ‘¥xitalic_x and rğ‘Ÿritalic_r. Hence, rğ‘Ÿritalic_r may contain additional information of yğ‘¦yitalic_y obtained from pretrained tasks that is hard to (or cannot) be directly extracted from xğ‘¥xitalic_x - the complex pretrained model assists in extracting relevant information in our two-stage generation, while one-stage generation solely relies on the single denoising model to do so. Therefore, by leveraging representations with provable error bounds, we can better shift the distribution towards the target.

In summary, rğ‘Ÿritalic_r is an ideal middle state connecting xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y - it is easy to recover rğ‘Ÿritalic_r from yğ‘¦yitalic_y (SectionÂ E.2.1) and to recover xğ‘¥xitalic_x from yğ‘¦yitalic_y (SectionÂ E.1.2), and vice versa. In comparison, it is somewhat more difficult to directly recover xğ‘¥xitalic_x from yğ‘¦yitalic_y or predict yğ‘¦yitalic_y from xğ‘¥xitalic_x. Consequently, rğ‘Ÿritalic_r may be a better indicator of yğ‘¦yitalic_y compared with xğ‘¥xitalic_x due to the aforementioned reasons.

Indeed, one-stage diffusion models generate xğ‘¥xitalic_x directly from conditions yğ‘¦yitalic_y need to optimize a highly complex score âˆ‡xlogâ¡pâ¢(x|y)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘¥ğ‘conditionalğ‘¥ğ‘¦\nabla_{x}\log p(x|y)âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p ( italic_x | italic_y ) where xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y are highly non-linearly mapped. As Theorem E.4 in (Yuan etÂ al., 2023) points out, the nonparametric SubOpt of xğ‘¥xitalic_x generated by deep neural networks is larger than our results in SectionÂ E.2.2, which further validates the advantage of first generating rğ‘Ÿritalic_r that can be well mapped from yğ‘¦yitalic_y.
